---

-> **Applications** : in curve fitting, density estimation (=modeling data distributions) with [[___INBOX___/__à trier/GMM|GMM]], ...
- *sub-differentials* : functions that are continuous but not differentiable at certain points

## 5.1 Differentiation of Univariate Functions

- ***Difference quotient*** : $\frac{\delta y}{\delta x}=\frac{f(x+\delta x) - f(x)}{\delta x}$
- Definition of ***the derivative*** : $\frac{df}{dx}=\lim\limits_{h\rightarrow 0}\frac{f(x+h)-f(x)}{h}$
	- -> the secant becomes a tangent
- *Example 5.2* : to find out derivative of $x^n$ without the formula but with the definition (limit)

### 5.1.1 - Taylor series
- a **Taylor series** is a representation of a function as an infinite sum of terms (determined using derivatives of $f$ evaluated at $x_0$)
	- $T_n(x):=\sum\limits_{k=0}^n \frac{f^{(k)}(x_0)}{k!}(x-x_0)^k$
	- ex (***power series representations***): $\sin\theta=\sum\limits_{k=0}^{\infty}(-1)^{k}\frac{1}{(2k+1)!}x^{2k+1}$
	- $\cos\theta=\sum\limits_{k=0}^{\infty}(-1)^{k}\frac{1}{(2k)!}x^{2k}$
- for $x_0=0$ we get a special case : the **MacLaurin series**
- if $f(x)=T_\infty(x)$ then $f$ is called ***analytic***
- $C^\infty$ mean continuously differentiable
- **Taylor polynomials** of degree $n$ : $T_n(x)$ -> ==it is **in general** an approximation of a function==
- *Remark* : A Taylor series is a special case of a power series => ?

### 5.1.2 - Differentiation Rules
> basic differentiation rules
- Product Rule -> $(fg)^\prime=f^\prime g + fg^\prime$
- Quotient Rule -> $(\frac{f}{g})^\prime=\frac{f^\prime g + fg^\prime}{g^2}$
- Sum Rule -> $(f+g)^\prime=f^\prime+g^\prime$
- [[Topics/Mathematics/Calculus/Chain Rule|Chain Rule]] -> $(g(f(x)))^\prime=(g\circ f)^\prime=(g(f))^\prime f^\prime$

---
## 5.2 - Partial Differentiation and Gradients

- The generalization of the derivative, to functions of several variables $f(x_1, x_2, ...)$ is called *==the gradient==*
- it's a **collection of partial derivatives** (varying one $x$ at a time, and keeping the others constant)
- Partial derivative $\mathbb{R}^n \rightarrow \mathbb{R}$
	- $\nabla_x f=grad f$ -> it is a ***row** vector*
		- **why ?** -> see the 2 explanations !
	- aka. the [[Jacobian]]

==TODO== (*example*)

### 5.2.1 - Basic rules of Partial differentiation
- -> the basic (high school) differentiation rules still applies
	- Product rule
	- Sum rule
	- Chain rule
- but pay attention, the order is important (matrix multiplications... not commutative)
	- from left to right
- see intuition of when $df$ cancels as in a fraction ... (but it's not "mathematically correct")

### 5.2.2 - Chain rule

==TODO== (*examples + re-read*)

- **==the chain rule can be written as a matrix multiplication==**
- but it only make sense if in *row vector "format"*
	- it make it easier (no matrix transposition)
	- but if we had a **tensor** => transposition is not trivial
- "Gradient checking" -> to check our code implementation ?

## 5.3 - Gradient of Vector-Valued Functions (p. 149)
- -> The **Jacobian** is a matrix collecting all the first-order partial derivatives of a vector-valued function (*Definition 5.6*) : $J=\nabla_x f$ is a $m\times n$ matrice
	- *==numerator layout==* is used here, where the element of $f$ defines the rows, and the elements of $x$ the columns. The other is the denominator layout
- In section 6.7 (Probability), to transform random variable & probabilty distributions
	- in context of ***reparametrization trick*** (aka. *infinite perturbation analysis*)
- The absolute value of the determinant of the Jacobian can be seen as a **scaling factor**
	- **Approach 1** : Linear Algebra
	- **Approach 2** : for non-linear ?

![Pasted image 20220328151357.png](data:image/png;base64,)
- Jacodian tensor (eg. if gradient of a matrix with respect to a vector)

## 5.4 - Gradient of Matrices
- When taking gradient of matrices with respect to vectors (or other matrices) => we can flatten by stacking the columns => $mn \times pq$ so we have a Jacobian matrix and not a tensor
	- because of vector-space isomorphism (linear & invertible mapping)
-

## 5.5 - Useful Identity for Computing Gradients
Frequently required in ML -> see ==Petersen & Pedersen, **2012**== (PDF : [[Petersen - The Matrix Cookbook - 2012.pdf]])

## 5.6 - Backpropagation and Automatic Differentiation
- the [[Topics/Machine Learning/Concepts/Basics/Backpropagation (1986)|backpropagation]] algorithm (Kelley, 1960; Bryson, 1961; Dreyfus, 1962; Rummelhart et al., 1986) to compute the gradient of an error function with respect to the parameters of the model

### 5.6.1 - Gradients in a Deep Network
- many-level function composition !
==TODO==

### 5.6.2 - Automatic Differentiation
- Backpropagation is a special case of a general techniques in [[___INBOX___/__à trier/Numerical analysis|Numerical analysis]] called *==automatic differentiation==* (autodiff)
	- numerically (instead of symbolically) compute gradient by working with intermediate variables & applying the [[Topics/Mathematics/Calculus/Chain Rule|Chain Rule]].
	- forward / reverse modes
		- -> see Baydin et al. (**2018**) - [*Automatic Differentiation in Machine Learning: A Survey* (arXiv)](https://arxiv.org/abs/1502.05767)
